summary: Indonesia is currently experiencing multiple natural disasters, primarily severe flash floods and cold lava flows from Mount Marapi in West Sumatra, which began on May 11[2]. The death toll from these events has risen to 67, with 20 people still missing, and earlier reports indicated 57 victims found dead and 22 missing[10]. These disasters have affected at least six regencies and cities, including Agam and Tanah Datar, destroying hundreds of homes and damaging public infrastructure[3]. President Joko Widodo has directed authorities to accelerate the rebuilding of damaged infrastructure, while rescue operations involve thermal drones, excavators, and manual searching for survivors[11]. Weather modification technology is being deployed to reduce rainfall intensity, and a state of emergency is in effect until May 26[22]. Concurrently, Mount Ibu in North Maluku Province has seen a series of eruptions since April, with a significant eruption on May 27 spewing ash 6km high, prompting the evacuation of residents from seven nearby villages and over 12,000 people from a nearby island[15][11][12]. The volcano's alert level has been elevated to IV, and aviation warnings have been issued[11]. Additionally, earlier in May, flooding in Ogan Komering Ulu, South Sumatra, affected 1,695 families and displaced 257, causing substantial material losses[14].

The ongoing volcanic activity of Mount Ibu has prompted significant emergency measures to ensure the safety and preparedness of affected communities. The Center for Volcanology and Geological Hazard Mitigation (PVMBG) has elevated the Ibu Volcano Alert Level to Alert Level IV, indicating a heightened state of alertness and potential danger[9]. In response, BPBD Halmahera Barat is on-site and has implemented an emergency alert status, known as "Siaga Darurat," to manage the situation effectively[9]. The country's volcanology agency has also issued warnings to aviation authorities managing local flights to prevent any aviation-related incidents due to the volcanic activity[10].

Authorities have communicated the urgent need for evacuation, resulting in the relocation of people from seven nearby villages and more than 12,000 individuals from a nearby island[11][10][12][1]. Residents affected by the eruption have been transported in pickup trucks and accommodated in emergency tents for the night[2]. To further support these efforts, the National Disaster Mitigation Agency (BNPB) and the PVMBG are planning to train a team of residents in each village surrounding the volcano to assist with any possible future evacuations[13].

In a related incident, the West Sumatra region has been severely impacted by flash floods and cold lava flows from Mount Marapi, resulting in a rising death toll that has reached 67 as of Thursday[14]. The progression of fatalities was reported as 43 on May 11, 44 by May 13, 50 by May 14, 52 by Tuesday, 57 by May 14, 58 by Wednesday, and 62 by Wednesday[15][16][17][18][14]. Approximately 3,200 people have been temporarily displaced to safer areas, with more than 3,000 evacuated[19][15]. As of Thursday, 20 people remain missing, with search and rescue operations ongoing, involving local rescuers, police, and military personnel[14][18][16][20]. The West Sumatra Police's elite Mobile Brigade Brimob has established a field kitchen in Sungai Pua village, Agam district, to provide cooked meals to villagers severely affected by the cold lava flood[5].

The AHA Centre, based in Jakarta, Indonesia, is tasked with coordinating disaster management among ASEAN Member States, offering early warning and impact analysis through DMRS[24][25]. This system serves all ASEAN Member States, enhancing their capacity to respond effectively to disasters[24].

The ongoing volcanic activity of Mount Ibu has prompted significant emergency measures and evacuations. The Center for Volcanology and Geological Hazard Mitigation (PVMBG) has elevated the alert status of Ibu Volcano to Alert Level IV due to recent volcanic activity, which has been communicated through various channels to ensure public safety and preparedness [9]. In response to the heightened alert, the country's volcanology agency has issued warnings to aviation authorities managing local flights [10]. Authorities have also initiated evacuations, moving people from seven nearby villages and more than 12,000 individuals from a nearby island to safer locations [11][10][12][1]. BPBD Halmahera Barat is actively on-site, implementing an emergency alert status known as "Siaga Darurat" to manage the situation [9].

In addition to these measures, the National Disaster Mitigation Agency (BNPB) and PVMBG are planning to train residents in each village surrounding the volcano to assist with potential future evacuations [13]. The BNPB is also employing weather modification technology, specifically cloud seeding, to redirect rain away from rivers on the volcano's slopes. This effort is in response to forecasts of moderate to heavy precipitation by the Meteorology, Climatology and Geophysics Agency (BMKG) [27][26][29].

Meanwhile, in another region, the danger zone around Mount Marapi has been extended westward by 3 kilometers from the summit due to lava flow moving toward Amakaka. This flow has reached 1,200 meters from the summit, impacting the village of Amakaka [28]. In Ogan Komering Ulu, 1,695 families have been affected by natural disasters, with 257 families displaced. The material losses include damage to 1,695 housing units, 4 worship facilities, a broken suspension bridge, and 10 hectares of agricultural land [3][4]. To support those affected by the cold lava flood from Mount Marapi, West Sumatra Police's elite Mobile Brigade Brimob has established a field kitchen in Sungai Pua village, Agam district, to provide cooked meals [5].

Additionally, the agricultural sector is facing challenges due to adverse weather conditions. Torrential rain and prolonged drought have severely impacted pepper farming, leading to dying plants, no harvest, and lower quality produce. Farmers have reported significant losses, with one expecting no harvest this year compared to nine tonnes last year, and another noting that the little harvest available is of lower quality, affecting future yields for 2024 and 2025 [6][7][8]. However, the sources do not specify that these agricultural impacts occurred in Indonesia.
